Title: An Introduction to Programming with Threads
AuthorList: Andrew D. Birrell. DEC Technical Report, January, 1989. Available: https://birrell.org/andrew/papers/035-Threads.pdf
Description: A classic but older introduction to threaded programming. Still a worthwhile read, and freely available.

Title: Programming with POSIX Threads
Description: Another one of these books on threads.

Title: PThreads Programming: by A POSIX Standard for Better Multiprocessing.
AuthorList: Dick Buttlar, Jacqueline Farrell, Bradford Nichols. O’Reilly, September 1996
Description: A reasonable book from the excellent, practical publishing house O’Reilly. Our bookshelves certainly contain a great deal of books from this company, including some excellent offerings on Perl, Python, and Javascript (particularly Crockford’s Javascript: The Good Parts”.)

Title: Programming With Threads
AuthorList: Steve Kleiman, Devang Shah, Bart Smaalders. Prentice Hall, January 1996.
Description: Probably one of the better books in this space. Get it at your local library. Or steal it from your mother. More seriously, just ask your mother for it – she’ll let you borrow it, don’t worry.

Title: Ad Hoc Synchronization Considered Harmful
AuthorList: Weiwei Xiong, Soyeon Park, Jiaqi Zhang, Yuanyuan Zhou, Zhiqiang Ma. OSDI 2010, Vancouver, Canada.
Description: This paper shows how seemingly simple synchronization code can lead to a surprising number of bugs. Use condition variables and do the signaling correctly!
